channel.title: Array Utility
channel.description:
I wrote this class because I find it very useful for my basic array needs and I'm sure it can replace lists if you want it to.
[url=http://pastebin.com/n3g8qwef]CLICK HERE FOR ArrayUtility.java[/url]

item.title: Array Utility
item.dc:creator: @wildskiller wildskiller
item.description:
@wildskiller wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:9, topic:549276”][quote author=wildskiller link=topic=668180.msg4469242#msg4469242 date=1422048260]

you could remove a lot of redundancy by using generic functions.

public <T> T[] reverse(T[] array) { ... } reverse(Int[]); reverse(String[]); reverse(Player[]);

I use generics for every non-primitive method. YOU CANNOT USE GENERICS FOR PRIMITIVES!

Why the hell doesn’t anyone actually take a look at the code?
[/quote]You can use the Number classes to use generics, while still allowing primitive arguments.

For example, I could get Integer[] from range(10, 50, 3), and use it just like an int[]. If you did it properly it would check type too; Integer[] range = range(5.3, 10.2, 0.5) would not compile.

It removes some method name redundancy but in the method itself you would have to have to check the type and cast, so you wouldn’t be saving THAT many lines of code, but you would be saving some.[/quote]
Alright. I’ve had so many people on r-s and here tell me that I need to use generics. I’ve used generics on every method, and you can’t use generics on primitive types. I will change the range methods from primitive to their parenting types

Read full topic

item.title: Array Utility
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“wildskiller, post:7, topic:549276”][quote author=imthenull link=topic=668180.msg4469229#msg4469229 date=1422040824]
you could remove a lot of redundancy by using generic functions.

public <T> T[] reverse(T[] array) { ... } reverse(Int[]); reverse(String[]); reverse(Player[]);
[/quote]
I use generics for every non-primitive method. YOU CANNOT USE GENERICS FOR PRIMITIVES!

Why the hell doesn’t anyone actually take a look at the code?[/quote]You can use the Number classes to use generics, while still allowing primitive arguments.

For example, I could get Integer[] from range(10, 50, 3), and use it just like an int[]. If you did it properly it would check type too; Integer[] range = range(5.3, 10.2, 0.5) would not compile.

It removes some method name redundancy but in the method itself you would have to have to check the type and cast, so you wouldn’t be saving THAT many lines of code, but you would be saving some.

Read full topic

item.title: Array Utility
item.dc:creator: @ExtremeX-Scape Ryley
item.description:
@ExtremeX-Scape wrote:

justaguy:

No map, reduce, zip, foldl/foldr??

Stream#of(varargs_array) and Arrays#stream(array) provide that already

Read full topic

[quote=“imthenull, post:4, topic:549276”]you could remove a lot of redundancy by using generic functions.

public <T> T[] reverse(T[] array) { ... } reverse(Int[]); reverse(String[]); reverse(Player[]);[/quote]
I use generics for every non-primitive method. YOU CANNOT USE GENERICS FOR PRIMITIVES!

Why the hell doesn’t anyone actually take a look at the code?

justaguy:

No map, reduce, zip, foldl/foldr??

What do you mean by that?

item.description:
@wildskiller wrote:

Miss Silabsoft:

you would of been better of extending ArrayList with those range methods. What are the practical use of them?

tbh, no idea; just wrote those for the hell of it, but the other methods are very useful
